data.title: EWA: Structural Tailwinds On One Hand, Slowdowns On The Other
data.description:
The Australian market hasn’t exactly been in the spotlight this year, but still fetching a fair 13% YTD return. Commodity dependent while also having an unusually concentrated banking sector and a unique geopolitical position, the Australian story isn’t a boring one for sure. We will be looking at the current macro environment, monetary policy, and some structural tailwinds for Australia, such as the relationship with the Chinese economy amid geopolitical volatility and its counter-cyclical dependency on the commodity market, and obviously the goal of this analysis- the iShares MSCI Australia ETF (EWA).

The Fund

The iShares MSCI Australia ETF aims to provide exposure to large and mid-sized companies in the Australian equity market. The ETF passively tracks the benchmark- MSCI Australia Index, which is meant to track the performance of approximately 85% of the free-float-adjusted market cap in the Australian capital markets. The weighting is market cap based, and around 91% of the holdings are classified as large cap (above $10 billion). The total number of constituents is 47. Moving on to the fund, the expense ratio is 0.5%, and coupled with the low bid/ask % spread of 0.04%, it earns a C+ Seeking Alpha expense grade. Liquidity is high, with an average daily dollar volume on a 3-month basis around $94 million and an AUM of $1.48 billion, and it is given an A Seeking Alpha Grade.

The banking sector is a dominant player in the capital markets in Australia in terms of traded companies, and it represents around 42% of the ETF holdings, followed by the Materials sector with around 19% and the Health Care sector with around 8%, as seen below:

To my knowledge there are two US-quoted ETFs offering exposure to Australia, EWA and Franklin FTSE Australia ETF (FLAU), and next we will compare the two using Seeking Alpha’s grading system.

Generally, we can’t come to a clear conclusion, as one ETF is better in one area while the other is better in another area. In short, FLAU offers a better expense ratio, as it is only 9 basis points, far below the 50 basis points for EWA. On the other hand, liquidity is much lower than EWA, with an AUM of $80 million for FLAU. The fund structure is also less concentrated for FLAU, with 54.31% of the fund assets concentrated in the top 10 holdings as opposed to 62.59% for EWA. FLAU has 105 holdings, while EWA has 58.

The performance is comparative between the two funds, short-term and long term. There is no data for a 10-year series for FLAU as it has existed since 2017, while EWA was incorporated in 1996.

The Bright Side

We’ll start off optimistic with the positive factors about the Australian economy and the companies in this ETF. Starting off with geopolitics, a big positive momentum has been building up with the normalization of bilateral relations with China, with the Australian Prime Minister describing the countries as “friends”. The ties between these countries are crucial in my opinion, as China is Australia’s biggest trading partner, especially significant for crucial trading materials such as iron ore, coal, and agricultural exports. A stable relationship means a predictable economy, and a predictable economy translates to growing positive investment sentiment. Continuing on that note, we’ll focus on the materials and mining sector, as I think it will play an important part in the outlook for the ETF ahead, and even though the bulk of the ETF is invested in the Financials sector, we have to remember that this sector is cyclical and traditionally has been etching out good performance when the economy is doing well, and Australia’s economy is dependent on the metals and mining sector.

Australia is also poised to benefit from the energy transition, with the country being one of the biggest players in the global mining production and reserves, especially for metals such as lithium, rare earth elements, nickel, copper and cobalt, all necessary for the clean energy supply chain and the EV transition. We can see in this research by IEA how crucial these metals are and their value in every technological chain, from renewable energy to electric cars. And according to the research:

In a scenario that meets the Paris Agreement goals (as in the IEA Sustainable Development Scenario [SDS]), their share of total demand rises significantly over the next two decades to over 40% for copper and rare earth elements, 60-70% for nickel and cobalt, and almost 90% for lithium. EVs and battery storage have already displaced consumer electronics to become the largest consumer of lithium and are set to take over from stainless steel as the largest end user of nickel by 2040.

This, in my opinion, is a clear structural driver for the Australian economy, given especially the government's clear indication that it intends to boost and support this sector through the Future Made in Australia National Interest Framework. The Materials sector represents around 20% of the fund’s assets, and for simplicity's sake, we won’t take into consideration the second-hand effects the sector has for the whole economy.

The Australian dollar is traditionally a cyclical currency and moves in line with commodity demand, and in my opinion, should hold firm or appreciate in the short term as the relationship with China stabilizes and we have a risk on global sentiment.

These are all positive catalysts for the ETF in my opinion and should provide upside in the short, medium, or long term.

Not All Shiny For The Land Down Under

Continuing with the Materials sector, aside from the structural demand for critical miners, Australia remains the largest exporter of iron ore, exporting around half of total iron ore exports and the outlook for the ore isn’t exactly bright. Headwinds like a drop in Chinese steel production which has been falling for some months now and the start of the Simandou project in Guinea is the largest unearthed iron ore reserve in the world and the increase of supply will negatively impact the iron ore industry in Australia.

A similar picture is present for coal, with the IEA forecasting coal demand to slightly increase in 2025 and decline to remain on the same level as the previous year. Interestingly, the IEA forecasts coal demand to decrease in China marginally, while demand in the US is expected to increase by 7% and to decrease in the EU by 2%. Australia is the second largest exporter of coal, behind Indonesia. Last month the Australian Treasury released a modeling result indicating that coal and gas exports are expected to decline by 50% in just five years as demand for the fossil fuels drops.

The Big Four

Moving on, the biggest sector concentration for this ETF is the banking sector and the Australian banking sector is somewhat unique as four banks dominate the whole industry. We can see that the Big Four are also dominant in this fund's assets:

Together, Commonwealth Bank of Australia (OTCPK:CBAUF), Westpac Bank Corporation (OTCPK:WEBNF), ANZ Group Holdings Limited (OTCPK:ANZGF) and National Australia Bank Limited (OTCPK:NABZY) have on their balance sheets the majority of deposits and loans. This concentrated structure has allowed them high profits, especially the last few years, as the Reserve Bank of Australia has enforced a restrictive monetary policy and high interest rates. As we know, banking is a cyclical industry, and profits are cyclical. One of the most important drivers of profit for these banks is the net interest margin. In my opinion, the cash target rate set out by the RBA has hit a plateau, and even though inflation spiked in Q3 to 3.2% compared to 2.1% in Q2, I do not think this will prompt the RBA to enforce a rate hike. Simultaneously, mortgage demand is booming, with the market being pumped by the new government initiative First Home Guarantee scheme, with a 5% deposit down for a mortgage. And this is all positive for the banking sector- short term.

Valuation

However, I do not think there is much upside to playing the banking sector in this story, as this ETF looks priced to perfection.

On a rolling 10 year basis, the current P/E multiple of 20.64x is more than two standard deviations higher than the 10 year average.

More over the Big Four, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Westpac Banking Corporation, National Australia Bank and ANZ Group Holdings all trade at a 30-45% higher P/B than their 5 year average.

The fund has entered into a downtrend, breaking below the 20 and 50-Day MA, while the 200-day MA has proven to be a support point.

Risks

The two risks that I would like to note are quite obvious. The housing market is critical to the Australian economy and the banking sector, as around 60% of the loans are housing loans. An overheated, sharply rising housing market is certainly a risk, especially given the cost of living crisis in the country. The obvious risk also for a US friendly state in the Asian Pacific region is geopolitics, even though we see moderation in the relationship with China, any troubling noise between the US and China could find Australia in the crosshairs.

Conclusion

The Australian capital market has had a good year so far, with positive catalysts being the improving relationship with China and the fact that Australia is a major source for some critical minerals necessary for the green transition, defense technologies, and the chip industry. The banking sector is also poised to have a good year with surging mortgage demand and with rising inflation in the last quarter proving to be a problem to the rate cut cycle. However, valuation being on the expensive side, elevated housing market risks, and the expected slowdown in demand for key exports both short term and long term, point me to a HOLD recommendation.

data.title: Amazon: Surging Share Price Following Massive Beat
data.description:
Article Thesis

Amazon.com, Inc. (AMZN) reported strong Q3 results on Thursday, showing particularly compelling AWS results. The company's shares surged by double-digits following the earnings release, as the market was happy about the company's profitability trajectory. Relative to the more expensive Magnificent 7 stocks, AMZN looks like a solid value, but it isn't a must-own investment at a price of $250, as some other big tech players look even better.

Past Coverage

I have written about Amazon.com here on Seeking Alpha in the past, with my most recent article being from three months ago. I gave AMZN a neutral rating back then, which worked out well so far -- on the day of the Q3 release, AMZN was up 3% from one quarter earlier, which is a decent return, but a little less than what investors got from the broad market. With one quarter having passed since my last article on Amazon, and with AMZN reporting its Q3 results on Thursday, it is time to update my views on the company.

What Happened?

During regular trading hours, Amazon.com was down 3% on Thursday, pulling back with the broad market and the tech-heavy NASDAQ (QQQ). But in after-hours trading, AMZN is up by a hefty 13% at the time of writing -- the result of the following earnings release:

We see that AMZN beat estimates on both lines, which is always a good thing. The revenue beat wasn't very large, at roughly 1%, but earnings per share trounced estimates, with AMZN's bottom-line number coming in 25% ahead of what Wall Street analysts were forecasting -- AMZN hit the highest analyst estimate perfectly. This was Amazon's fifth double beat in a row, but it was the biggest profit beat in absolute terms, which could explain why investors were so happy with AMZN's earnings report, although I believe that Amazon's consolidating share price in the recent past may also help explain the positive reaction -- the market didn't seem very enthusiastic about Amazon going into this earnings report.

Amazon.com: Strong Profitability

Amazon's company-wide revenue growth of 13% was appealing, I believe. After all, Amazon's gigantic revenues in absolute terms make it quite hard to maintain a very high relative growth rate -- considering this, I think that the 13% revenue increase is very solid, even though tech peers like Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) and Meta Platforms (META) have reported better relative growth for the third quarter. During the second quarter, revenues had grown by 13% as well, thus we can say that there is neither significant positive nor significant negative momentum on a company-wide scale.

Amazon's business is split into three main sections, which can differ quite a lot when it comes to growth, profitability, etc. Amazon's biggest unit in terms of revenue generation is the U.S. retail business, where around 60% of company-wide revenue is being generated. The U.S. business grew by 11%, relative to one year earlier, which was in line with the growth rate one quarter earlier -- no big surprise here. The international business grew a little faster, at 14% versus the previous year's quarter, which is partially due to a weakening U.S. Dollar -- on a currency-neutral basis, the international segment grew by 10%, which is more or less in line with the U.S. business.

Amazon's growth star, of course, is AWS: During the third quarter, the unit saw sales expand to $33 billion, which made for a 20% increase versus one year earlier. Considering this is now a ~$130 billion a year tech unit, a 20% annual growth rate seems quite compelling to me. Here, we also saw positive momentum: AWS's growth rate was 18% during the second quarter, thus, growth did not only remain strong, it actually accelerated. That bodes well for the current quarter and 2026, I think, assuming Amazon can maintain positive momentum. Since AWS offers some AI exposure, the ongoing AI trend/hype seems to have a positive impact on Amazon's highest-margin business.

Revenue growth is good, but investors want to see profits, of course. Here, Amazon did well, too -- at least if we correct Amazon's reported numbers for some one-time items. Operating profit was $17.4 billion for the third quarter, in line with one year earlier. But that was due to two one-time items that "hide" Amazon's underlying profit growth. The company settled a legal issue with the FTC, which cost $2.5 billion, and the company experienced a charge of $1.8 billion for the planned massive layoffs that were announced a couple of days ago. Backing out those two items, Amazon would have generated an operating profit of $21.7 billion, which would mean growth of 25% versus one year earlier. Not only is that a pretty nice growth rate in general, it also means that AMZN's margins expanded nicely -- the operating profit growth rate was almost twice as high as the revenue growth rate.

This was, not surprisingly, partially driven by growing AWS profits, but Amazon's retail business did well, too. Backing out the aforementioned charge, the U.S. business (which is more profitable than the international business) saw profits expand by $1.6 billion over the last year. Low fuel expenses due to low oil prices helped with profitability, but Amazon also benefited from operating leverage that results in margin expansion as the company expands, all else equal. Amazon's AWS profits were up by $1.0 billion, before accounting for layoff expenses, which were not broken down on a business unit basis.

Net income was impacted by the above charges to operating earnings, but also saw a one-time impact from Amazon's stake in AI company Anthropic becoming more valuable -- AMZN booked a $9.5 billion pre-tax gain in Q3, which helps explain how Amazon was able to beat profit estimates so easily.

Amazon's operations are capital-intensive, both for the retail business -- warehouses, trucks, etc. -- as well as for the tech business, where huge data center investments are needed. With Artificial Intelligence investing picking up at AMZN, as well as at its peers, capital expenditures rose substantially over the last year. That's why free cash flows declined, despite operating cash flows improving: Operating cash flows over the last twelve months totaled $131 billion, up 16% over the previous year, but due to capital expenditures of $116 billion over the last year, free cash flow declined to only $15 billion.

For a company that is valued at roughly $2.7 trillion, that's not a lot -- the trailing free cash flow multiple is 180 or so. One can argue that capital expenditures will not always remain this high, and that major AI and data center investments will result in better operating cash flow and profits down the road, but I think that the discrepancy between the company's free cash flows and its market capitalization shouldn't be completely ignored by AMZN bulls.

Is Amazon A Good Investment?

The valuation looks better when we focus on profits instead of free cash flows, but even then, Amazon isn't a bargain. The company is forecasted to earn $6.65 or so this year, with shares trading at around $250 following the earnings release -- this makes for a 38x earnings multiple. Even when we account for some earnings estimate upside revisions in the coming days following AMZN's Q3 earnings beat, the valuation will remain in the mid-to-high-30s. That's not expensive compared to where Nvidia (NVDA), Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), or Tesla (TSLA) are trading -- but Magnificent 7 peers Meta Platforms and Alphabet are considerably cheaper, despite growing even faster than Amazon.

That is why I'm not an AMZN bull at current prices: With cheaper, faster-growing tech giants with AI exposure available today, I see more value elsewhere -- that doesn't mean that AMZN is a bad company at all, just that it is a less opportune investment compared to alternatives.

data.title: Microsoft: Q3 Earnings Were Flawless, Stock Is A Buy
data.description:
Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) reported an all-around beat for fiscal Q1 '26 on October 29, but the market did not seem to love what they saw. The stock is trading about 3% lower on the day as I type this sentence, despite a strong print and a short-term outlook that does not seem to raise any red flags.

It would be silly to call for a pound-the-table, post-earnings buy-the-dip opportunity in this case, since MSFT has been up 29% YTD (see below) and 38% since I pointed out an opportunity to ride a potential rally ahead, less than eight months ago. However, I believe that the stock remains a compelling long-term buy-and-hold for reasons that I revisit below, following my brief analysis of fiscal Q1 results and guidance.

Quick Look At The Results

I invite readers to go through Seeking Alpha's coverage of Microsoft's earnings release in detail, from the performance of each of the company's segments to the takeaways from the earnings call. I was impressed by several key items on Microsoft's report, particularly:

  1. The largest EPS beat and third-largest revenue beat vs. expectations in the past 20 quarters.
  2. The largest YOY growth rate in the two segments that matter most, business processes and cloud, going back at least nine quarters.
  3. An Azure business that, rather than maturing and slowing down, seems to be accelerating (see chart below).
  4. Strong op margin expansion (48.9% in the recent quarter vs. 46.6% in the comparable period last year) that was clearly driven by scale, as gross margins did not pick up any tailwind, but operating expenses (particularly sales and marketing) remained well under control.

I believe that the last point above flies under many investors' radars, yet it helps to justify my bull thesis on the company and stock. As the chart below clearly depicts, Microsoft has managed to deliver operating profits as consistently and predictably as one could expect. This is the result, in my view, of Microsoft's transition to what is now mostly a SaaS- and subscription-based business model under the leadership of Satya Nadella.

As I wrote in a Microsoft article that is now about seven years old, "recurring revenue offers revenue predictability" and "the stock market [...] places a higher value on predictable recurring revenue as it translates into meaningful valuation." Yes, Microsoft's F1Q was impressive as a stand-alone quarter. But more importantly, it helped to cement the idea that the company, even at a massive scale, can still deliver what I believe to be what investors value the most: predictable, high-margin, cash-flow-rich results.

This is a perfect segue to the next topic, my perma-bull thesis on MSFT.

The Perma-bull Thesis On MSFT

Microsoft is one of those businesses that I have never turned bearish on, once I understood the value proposition in 2018. This is not to say that I am blind to the risks of investing in the company's equity (although, to be fair, MSFT has historically been the least volatile stock of all within the Mag 7 peer group). It also does not mean that I would never abandon my bull thesis as a matter of loyalty to the company or my convictions.

As I presented several times in the past, value perception is primarily a function of two factors above any other: risk and growth. On the risk side, the chart immediately above provides a visual representation of how consistently at delivering results, Microsoft has been for many years.

The company's balance sheet also helps to support the case. As of the most recent period, Microsoft held nearly $60 billion in net cash, defined here as cash and liquid investments less short- and long-term debt. This is in part why the company can so easily afford to invest in infrastructure to ride the tailwinds of the cloud and AI revolutions.

In addition, Microsoft's net working capital (current assets except cash, minus current liabilities except debt) is -$40 billion (net liability positive), which is astounding when coupled with cash flow from operations of $147 billion in the trailing twelve months. Not unlike its peer Apple (AAPL), this means that Microsoft is able to create lavish amounts of cash "out of thin air" — that is, while having its operations financed primarily by its customers and vendors.

The growth side of the valuation equation is what I believe more clearly supports my bullish stance. While MSFT's trailing EPS multiple of 38.3x (see above) may keep value investors at bay, merely looking forward a couple of years helps to understand why the share price is likely to grow into a next-year P/E that currently sits at "only" 28.7x. With fiscal 2028 P/E at 24.3x today, one of two things must be true: either (1) Microsoft will disappoint analysts and investors and deliver below-consensus EPS going forward, which the company virtually never does, or (2) MSFT stock will more than likely climb towards an EPS valuation above 30x through the next 2–3 years, which is much more reasonable for a stock of this quality.

For the reasons outlined above, I maintain my perma-bull stance on MSFT. While a 3% single-session pullback may not be enough to call this a dip-buying opportunity, it is better than nothing: I am accumulating shares on this modest pullback.

data.title: Apple Q3: Stocks Crash, Then Rise - Why? (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
Apple Inc.'s (AAPL) Q3 earnings were just released, and something truly absurd happened in the markets.

As soon as the results were released, the market read the lower-than-expected China data and rushed to sell the stock. The stock lost $130 billion in market capitalization in just one minute, falling 5% in after-hours trading. Not even five minutes have passed, and the stock is up 8% from its low, adding $320 billion to the market capitalization, going from a selloff to a strong buy. I believe such a massive and rapid movement of money has rarely been seen in history. Let's analyze the numbers and understand what happened.

Earnings Season

Without further ado, I'll tell you that the quarterly results were released without too many flaws, textbook, and without any gray areas. Record revenues of $102.47 billion (+7.9% year-over-year) and earnings per share of $1.85 (estimated at $1.77). It was the best September quarter in the company's history, driven by double-digit growth in services (+15%) and a significant recovery in the Mac (+13%), while the iPhone maintained a solid pace of expansion (+6%).

The main driver was the services segment, which added $28.75 billion in revenue, an all-time high thanks to the expansion of the App Store, Google licenses, AppleCare, and digital subscriptions. The CFO specified that growth was double-digit in almost all categories and regions. Here, in addition to highlighting revenues, I'd like to focus on the stability of margins; in fact, the gross margin exceeded expectations thanks to the growing weight of services.

The Wearables, Home, and Accessories categories also performed strongly, totaling $9 billion and beating estimates by $8.6 billion. Demand for the AirPods Pro 3 and Apple Watch SE, which had remained flat for several quarters, has indeed returned. The CFO reported $1.1 billion in tariff costs in the quarter, a figure that explains why operating expenses (+11% year-over-year) rose more than expected. Yet, they did not impact profitability, further demonstrating how Apple manages to defend margins even in unfavorable geopolitical environments.

The sore point remains the same. The Achilles heel that once accounted for 20% of revenues has now fallen to around 15%. China, the company's third-largest market. This is not the first time we have seen it, yet it is a really unstable market, therefore results in that area frequently decide income. Apple has fallen today in that region. Revenue decreased 3.6% to $14.5 billion, some 12% below analysts' estimates. I believe that while the weight of rivalry was felt, limitations on AI characteristics (not accessible in the nation) also had detrimental consequences. These statistics caused the market to initiate the selloff I previously described, therefore erasing $130 billion in market capitalization within minutes (or seconds).

In any case, I don't believe this is a structural weakness, but rather a temporary effect. Some iPhone 16 and 17 models are still limited by production capacity (management itself has confirmed this), and this explains much of the slowdown in sales. So it's not a question of demand, but of availability, and I believe that in this case, it's better to have a production constraint than a loss of market share. Don't you think so?

It's worth noting, however, that the $1.9 billion decline in sales in China was more than offset, in absolute terms, by sales exceeding $2.3 billion in Europe. This, combined with the CEO's guidance, may be why the stock recovered from the initial shock of the Chinese results.

Indeed, CEO Tim Cook, during the conference call, expressed confidence in a "return to growth in the holiday quarter" and highlighted record results in India, which recorded its best quarter ever. According to forecasts, Apple therefore expects growth of 10% to 12% in the quarter ending in December, with iPhone sales experiencing "double-digit growth" (the consensus was around +8%).

Cook also mentioned the $600 billion investment plan in the United States over the next four years, in an attempt to approximate President Trump's model of bringing manufacturing back home while protecting the supply chain.

On the cost front, expenses have remained under control and cash remains abundant at $132 billion, strengthening financial visibility for buybacks and AI investments. With CNBC, Cook mentioned that a "more personalized" Siri is in the pipeline for next year and also hinted at additional collaborations with ChatGPT, which indicates a subtle shift towards AI direct monetization." ​‍​‌‍​‍‌I was really excited about this, but it's finally coming.

Valuation & Market Reaction

The stock's reaction was initially nervous, due to the China shock. Then, the rebound was supported by better-than-expected guidance and margins. Operationally, the balance sheet remains solid, but I had no doubts about that. Gross margins rose above expectations, operating costs remained under control, and the company continued to aggressively return capital (approximately $90.7 billion in buybacks this year) while keeping the dividend stable at $0.26 per share.

Gross cash (cash and short-term securities) is $132 billion in gross cash, meaning there's virtually no need for leverage for any type of investment. The money is there. Simple. This gives management rare freedom. They can continue to return capital to shareholders—and do so aggressively, with record buybacks—without having to sacrifice strategic investments in AI.

The 10–12% growth target for the December quarter sounds believable to me and, in my view, draws emphasis away from geographic volatility—the "China case," Apple's problem) to margin resilience and the more lucrative service mix, which is expanding in double digits. Personally, I am rather unconcerned about the (temporary) China problem—particularly if it's connected to supply restrictions (rather than demand) and if sales in Europe, Japan, and APAC compensate well.

Rating Update

I​‍​‌‍​‍‌ am not trying to follow the trend of the market. I pass from Buy to Strong Buy. I had already gone the other way, in fact, at one point, I gave it a Sell rating. I was mistaken, I acknowledged it, and I am acknowledging it once again.

The recent figures have removed a large part of the doubts that I had. To summarize, demand is stable, margins are solid, and management is working hard, raising the next quarter's ​‍​‌‍​‍‌forecasts.

What really changes the situation, for me, are services. They are the engine that brings stability and visibility to Apple's financials. They are growing at a double-digit rate in almost all regions, with margins above 70%. Truly interesting.

And then, show me another company that generates around $100 billion in free cash flow each year, with $132 billion in gross cash, and still absorbs over $1 billion in tariff costs without affecting margins.

On artificial intelligence, I have flip-flipped. A few quarters back I was very skeptical and critical; Apple appears to have made no headway. I wrote it and I shall say it once again. I was not right. The new partnerships outside ChatGPT and the redesigned Siri in 2026 finally offer a believable path toward artificial intelligence's monetization inside the Apple ecosystem. And I'm drawn to that.

Given its enormous visibility and cash flow, Apple is not pricey at present price/earnings levels, but it is also not inexpensive either. Should China grow again and if first AI monetization comes, the potential upside results are huge.

Conclusion

After a quarter like this, the risk isn't buying too early, but staying out. I've made this mistake in the past by reducing my exposure to the stock, thinking I was outsmarting the market and playing for timing. Today, the story is different. Apple has returned to being a story to hold, not to chase. The market was confused after the data was released, but as soon as it had time to better understand the financial data, it shifted toward buying. Margins are solid, services are expanding, and AI is starting to become tangible.

In my portfolio, Apple has become a core stock, like in the old days. You purchase on drawdowns and let it work. Because the mix of FCF, cash, and earnings visibility successfully covers the valuation premium, I don't see the risk of multiple compression in the near term.

data.title: Chipotle Mexican Grill's Rancid Plunge Offers A Tasty Opportunity

Oct. 30 was a very painful day for shareholders of Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc. (CMG). Shares of the company plummeted 18.2% after management announced financial results covering the third quarter of the company's 2025 fiscal year. Revenue fell a bit short of expectations. More disappointing than these results, however, was the fact that management reduced guidance for comparable store sales for this year because of consumer headwinds. In the past, I have been more neutral on the business, even reaffirming it as a "Hold" candidate back in January of this year. The fact of the matter is that shares were too expensive for my liking, even though I am a huge fan of the restaurant. However, the thing that stopped me from downgrading it to a "Sell" was the fact that the company was continuing to achieve impressive growth.

Fast forward to today, and things are not going well. The stock is down 45.6% over the last year, with management now warning that comparable restaurant sales will be down this year as opposed to flat. For many investors, this would be an ideal time to cash out and look elsewhere for opportunities. However, I actually think now might be the time to step in and upgrade it. To be clear, the company has difficult days ahead for it, and I fully expect conditions to worsen before they get better. The United States is spiraling toward a recession, in my opinion, and I fully anticipate consumer pressures to hurt the company more than they have already. Normally, the kind of valuation that the firm trades at would justify a neutral rating, though just barely. But with the company still focused tremendously on growth and with it having no debt and a huge amount of cash on hand, I think that those who are in it for the long haul should consider it a very soft "Buy" candidate.

Tough Times

After the market closed on Oct. 29, the management team at Chipotle Mexican Grill announced financial results covering the third quarter of the company's 2025 fiscal year. Revenue for the company came in at $3 billion, which was up from the $2.79 billion reported last year, but it also ended up missing analysts’ expectations by $19.1 million. In the grand scheme of things, this kind of miss is mostly a rounding error. However, when you have a restaurant operator that has historically been priced like a technology company, even meeting expectations can result in downside if the market catches even a whiff of weakness ahead. In short, Chipotle Mexican Grill has been priced for perfection, and it has fallen short of that.

The overall growth in revenue for the company came from a rise in the number of locations that it has in operation, from 3,615 last year to 3,916 this year. There was also a slight increase in comparable store sales, amounting to 0.3%. But that's far worse than the 6% increase that the company saw in the same quarter last year on a year-over-year basis. What was really problematic is the fact that the comparable store sales for the company were driven entirely by higher prices, with the average check rising by 1.1%. At the same time as this, the number of transactions dropped by 0.8%.

I am not a big believer in the value of anecdotes. But the second investment book that I ever read was One Up On Wall Street by Peter Lynch. In that book, I became fascinated by the fact that he would often physically check in on the companies that he was considering buying to get a full understanding of the strengths and weaknesses of the business in person. Keeping in mind that a single visit to a single location does not offer significant value if our goal is to get an understanding of the health of the business as a whole, I would like to mention that just a month ago, I visited one of the Chipotle Mexican Grill restaurants near my home. I am a big fan of its food, and I consider myself a foodie. I was shocked when, probably around 1:00 PM, I walked in and was the only customer for the business to service. The number of employees seemed low, and honestly, the food was not as fresh as it should have been. It was a rather disappointing experience for a chain that has a history of lines going to or even exiting out of its doors.

I should have used that experience to buy some put options on the stock, but I didn't. However, I doubt that this is so much a company-specific issue as it is a consumer issue. Management continues to focus on innovations, including those involving its menu and investing in digital orders. In fact, the firm went from generating 34% of its food and beverage sales through digital means in the third quarter of last year to generating 36.7% of them at the same time this year. I think the bigger problem is precisely what management hit on, which is that consumer headwinds and macroeconomic challenges remain a problem.

Let's be honest: when it comes to food, Chipotle Mexican Grill is not the go-to place if your goal is to maintain a strict budget. It's the place that you go to if you want food that is of a higher quality and don't mind paying a little bit more than what fast food joints would charge you. During difficult times, I would imagine that Chipotle Mexican Grill would struggle. As I have detailed in other articles, like here and here, the U.S. economy seems to be heading toward a recession. Jobs data is getting worse almost by the month. And with tariffs now at play, there is a real risk of economic contraction in the near future. I have been arguing this since August. It is the first time in my professional career that I have ever said a recession is practically guaranteed. Even consumer confidence is near an all-time low, as the chart above illustrates.

Even though revenue for the company increased, the profitability worsened. Earnings per share did rise from $0.28 to $0.29. But that was only thanks to a change in share count. Overall net income grew from $387.4 million to $382.1 million. In the chart above, you can see important costs in relation to overall revenue. The good news is that food, beverage, and packaging expenses have actually gotten a bit better for the company. But other costs are on the rise, including labor expenses and occupancy costs. The big problem, however, seems to be its "other operating costs," which rose from 13.83% of sales to 15%. Management blamed this on increased marketing and promotional activities and lower sales volumes. Fortunately, as the first chart in this article illustrates, cash flow metrics for the business at least improved.

In the chart above, you can see financial results for the first nine months of 2025 compared to the same time last year. In this case, results did improve across the board. But overall, the company remains challenged. So far, comparable restaurant sales this year are down 1.4%, even though the company benefited to the tune of 1.3% from higher prices. But again, consumer confidence is incredibly weak right now, and even small price increases can have an impact on traffic. In fact, the number of transactions that the company saw was down 2.7% year over year. Until economic conditions improve or until management can do something to draw more customers into its doors, such as effective promotions, menu cost reductions, or new and innovative offerings at its restaurants, I expect worsening economic conditions to lead to more of this pain as time goes on.

Management has even had to reduce guidance for this year. Earlier in the year, they anticipated that overall comparable restaurant sales would be mostly flat. But now they expect them to be down at a low single-digit rate. Despite this, the company is pushing forward with its growth plans. It still intends to open between 315 and 345 locations this year, with 80% of those boasting a Chipotlane. According to some estimates, a Chipotlane typically boosts overall restaurant sales by between 10% and 15%, also leading to greater margins and overall returns. So it is great to see investments being made in these.

Next year, management intends to push growth even further, opening between 350 and 370 locations. That will involve between 10 and 15 international locations as the company continues to focus on a population that is drastically larger than what the United States consists of. This does not mean that the company will slow down its growth in North America anytime soon. In fact, management expects to eventually expand its physical footprint to 7,000 restaurants in North America.

This kind of growth justifies, in my view, the stock as a very soft "Buy" rating at this time. If we project our results based on what we have seen already this year, we would expect net profits of $1.54 billion, adjusted operating cash flow of $2.14 billion, and EBITDA of $2.32 billion. Using these estimates, we can see in the chart above how shares of the company are currently valued. Relative to what the company was valued at using data from last year, shares are a bit cheaper. But not radically so. The stock is certainly cheaper than it was when I last wrote about it. And now, as you can tell by looking at the table below, it is priced around the middle of what other similar enterprises are priced at. Considering its growth trajectory and potential, and adding on top of this the fact that it has no debt and has $698.7 million of cash on its books, I think that there are reasons to be cautiously optimistic.

Takeaway

Based on all the data provided, I can understand why investors are probably disappointed right now. But honestly, I think that now is the time to be a little bit bullish. I fully anticipate that financial results will worsen in the near term. And investors should be prepared for that. But I believe that this has more to do with the consumer and the state of the economy than it does with the health of the business. Management does need to do certain things to draw more customers in. However, given its strong balance sheet and growth ambitions, I think that there are more reasons to be optimistic than pessimistic.

data.title: FRA: Leveraged Loan Fund With A Macro Issue
data.description:
Thesis

BlackRock Floating Rate Income Strategies Fund Inc (FRA) is a closed end fund we have not covered before. The CEF comes from BlackRock and focuses on leveraged loans.

In today's article we are going to review this CEF, its structure and analytics, and outline why we believe the fund to have significant downside in the next 12 months given the current macro outlook and fund internals.

Fund composition - leveraged loans

FRA is a classic leveraged loans closed end fund:

  • Term loans: 95%
  • Equity: 4%
  • CLO: 1%

The name holds mostly leveraged loans outright, with a small sleeve for equity (from restructurings) and a small CLO sleeve. The name is overweight single-B credits which make up the majority of the holdings:

  • BBB: 6%
  • BB: 29%
  • B: 57%
  • CCC: 5%
  • Not rated: 3%

The composition is fairly typical for a leveraged loan CEF, with a 22% gearing ratio on top. So far, so good. The fund has a granular build, with the vast majority of the holdings under 1% of the fund (only 6 names represent more than 1%, with the maximum concentration at 1.9%).

Historic performance - in line with peers

The CEF does not have an outstanding historic performance, its total return falling in line with peers:

On a 5-year lookback FRA has posted a total return profile that closely correlates with VVR and JFR. This simply means that the management team has done a similar job as their peers. We can observe that until recently only VVR was the outperformer from this cohort. However, in the past year FRA has outperformed both VVR and JFR. We will explore shortly why, in the Premium/Discount section.

Premium/Discount to NAV

FRA has outperformed its peers this year, not due to outstanding management decisions, but the market perception of its peers:

JFR and VVR seem to have a bigger retail investor base, base which started pricing in lower Fed Funds and the changing macro environment. FRA has lagged in doing so, with the CEF still at an astounding premium to NAV of 2.3%. We are of the opinion this state of affairs will change, with the CEF set to move to a discount as the market prices correctly the current macro.

Since historically FRA does not show any alpha to its peers, it is set to being valued similarly, i.e. at a discount. We shall show you the macro drivers responsible for this.

Macro drivers: lower fed funds and tight spreads

Leveraged loans are floating rate, meaning they pay SOFR plus a spread. As Fed Funds move lower, SOFR moves lower, hence the all-in yield paid by leveraged loans decreases. What does this mean? It means in such an environment investors tend to move away from floating rate assets into fixed rate assets.

On October 29, 2025 the Fed cut rates yet again, bringing the effective Fed Funds target rate to 3.75%-4%:

Investors can debate where the neutral rate lies, but one thing is certain: rates are moving lower. Is the neutral rate 3% or is it 2%? One can debate this for a while, but at the end of the day SOFR is headed lower, and all-in yields for leveraged loans are headed lower.

The second macro headwind for leveraged loans is made up of tight credit spreads. We have compressed to a level in spreads that is at the bottom of a 10-year range. This simply means the market is very complacent, and during a risk-off event spreads are headed higher. Higher spreads means lower prices for leveraged loans, which means a lower NAV for a fund like FRA. While we do not have a crystal ball to predict the exact timing, it will eventually happen in the next 12 months. It is just a matter of time.

Current dividend is unsustainable

The CEF is currently paying a 11.88% distribution, but this level is unsustainable:

Even before the most recent Fed action, the CEF was paying out an unsustained dividend. As we can see from its August 2025 Section 19a notice, the CEF was using 32% return of capital. This is a very large figure that will become larger as lower rates percolate down the holdings. Please note many leveraged loans are set off 3-months SOFR, meaning a lower Fed Funds level will take a few months to translate into a lower all-in yield. It is coming however.

Using the above 32% ROC figure gives us an actual cash supported distribution of below 9%. That level will be cemented by lower Fed Funds. Math points towards a cut in the distribution rate to make it more sustainable. We see the fund moving to a 9% or 10% distribution rate in the next few months, thus still using ROC but a lower amount of it.

Investors hate distribution cuts, and we believe that is why we have not seen this yet happen, but the management team will not have a choice.

Conclusion

FRA is a leveraged loan CEF. The name is negatively impacted by lower Fed Funds, and has an overhang in terms of tight credit spreads. Surprisingly the CEF is still trading at a premium to NAV while its peers are at discounts close to -10%. The fund's distribution is not supported, with the latest Fed cut suggesting a supported cash distribution closer to 9%. We are of the opinion that the CEF will end up cutting its distribution and moving to a discount to NAV, thus putting pressure on its price.
